The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe President of the Board oi Trade (Paper CP. -08' (27)) on the subject of the Brussels convention on Immunity of State-owned Ships, in which theywere asked to decide (i) Whether the principle of the draftlb. Convention should be accepted,and(ii) Whether, if the principle is accepted ,the Convention should only be ratified providing that additional safeguardsare introduced into the supplementary Protocol whichwill be satisfactory to the law: Officers of the Crown,Under-together with a Note by the/ Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs pointing out how embarrassingwould ba a refusal to accept a Convention at all(Paper C.P.-7C (27)) .The Cabinet agreed (a) That the Attorney-General should introduce such additional safeguardsas he deemed necessary into the supplementary Protocol:(b) Subject to this, that the draftInternational Convention for the unification of certain rulesrelating to Immunity of State-owned vessels should be approved, and thatthe negotiations with the BelgianGovernment for its acceptance shouldbe proceeded with. a. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Minister of Transport (Paper CP.-53 (27))on the subject of the Report of the Royal Cominis-sion on Cross-River Traffic in London (Cmd.2772),containing proposals as to the decisions whichshould be taken on the Report; together with aNote by the Chancellor of the Exchequer (paper cp.-58 (27)) covering a Memorandum by theTreasury suggesting that the present is not thetime to.enter into a heavy programme of commit-ments such as that recommended by the RoyalCommission, and containing alternative proposals.After considerable discussion the cabinet agreed (a) That loan operations of the kindindicated in the Report of theRoyal Commission could not becontemplated by His Majesty'sGovernment.(b) That no new central authority for london Bridges, as proposed by theRoyal Commission, should be constituted.(c) To approve the recommendations ofthe Royal Commission in regard toWaterloo Bridge.(d) That as regards the proposed double-decker bridge at Charing Cross, whileit was recognised that a decision notto widen Waterloo Bridge to the extentpreviously proposed by the LondonGounty Council would necessitate theprovision of a new Road Bridge atthis point, a decision to proceedwith the specific scheme recommendedby the Royal Commission should be deferred until proper estimates of cost have been obtained, by theMinistry of Transport from responsibleengineers of high standing. should it appear that the proposals are substantially more costly thanthey are estimated to be by theRoyal Commission, the matter willrequire reconsideration. (e) That as regards the proposed LudgateBridge, the Government should offer the City Corporation, if they decide to proceed with this scheme in pre-ferar.ce to the St. Pauls Bridgescheme, a grant on the same basis as they had contemplated in thecase of that scheme, viz., 50 percent, of the net cost of the roadapproaches.(f) To approve the recommendations of theRoyal Commission in regard to the victoria Docks Road.(g) That, without prejudice to Treasurycontrol of Road Fund finance, theMinister of Transport should beauthorised to make his plans on theassumption that grants up to an amountnot largely exceeding 1,000,000 inany one year will be available from.the Road Fund for the above projects and for those named in (h) belowduring the next few years .(h) That, as regards schemes recommendedby the Royal Commission other thanthose expressly named above, theMinister of Transport should beauthorised to negotiate with theauthorities for grants of a suitablepercentage of expenditure within thelimits of expenditure named inparagraph (g) above as funds areavailable from the Road Fund, in theorder of urgency and importance fromthe traffic aspect of the respectiveprojects(i) That the announcement to be made onthis subject should be concertedbetween the Minister of transport and the Chancellor of the Exchequer, .and should be drafted with the aim of avoiding any suggestion of extravagance.The announcement should indicate thatthe Report of the Royal commission had revealed that certain schemes were urgent; that, subject to theresult of negotiations with theLocal Authorities concerned, these schemes would be proceeded with, and contributions' would be made from theRoad Fund as funds. became available.(j) That the Minister of Transport should'be authorised to inform the LondonCounty Council of the decision inregard to Waterloo Bridge, withoutdelay. lp'lON andbAiioN opfeviousfereno e:cabinet 7Oon-conclusion 1 &Ipenaix.)3. The Cabinet had before them the Minutesof the 222nd Meeting of the Committee of ImperialDefence on the subject of Reduction and Limita-tion of Armaments, together with a copy of thedraft Convention, prepared by the Sub-Committeeof the Committee of Imperial Defence on Reduc-tion and Limitation of Armaments, which theCommittee of Imperial Defence proposed, subjectto certain amendments, should form the basis for the instructions of the British representa-tives at the forthcoming meeting of the Prepara-tory Commission at Geneva (Paper CP.-78 (27));+ p" i". - --aha a Memorandum by the Chancellor ofthe Duchy of Lancaster (Paper CP.-79 (.27)).The Cabinet agreed - Subject to a modification of thelast sentence (incorporated below)to accept the recommendations ofthe Committee of Imperial defence in the following form:-To approve the draft convention for the limitation of naval,military and air armaments asthe basis for the instructions of the British representatives at the forthcoming meetings ofthe Preparatory Commission atGeneva, subject to the following amendments:-(a) Paragraph 3 (2): To be omitted.(b) Paragraph 7: To be excluded.(c) Paragraph 13, Lines 4 & 5:Omit the words "or is incurringexpenditure on land armaments inexcess of the figures set out inTable I or Annex I".(d) Paragraph 13, Line 6: Omit thewords "at once"; and subject to the understanding thatthe Eritish delegates will opposeany proposal for the creation of aspecial League Commission or other special organ for the purpose of examining the information to be furnished under the provisions ofthe draft Convention.-4 a- lios opOP WORK.nat 13Con-ion 4')a.. The Cabinet had before them the firstInterim Report of the Cabinet Committee on theWashington Hours Convention (Paper C.P.-77 (27)),in which it was recommended that a Bill shouldbe drafted dealing with the question of hoursof employment, in industrial undertakings inGreat Britain, the provisions of which should follow, in the main, the existing industrial conditions in this country and should be calcu-lated to interfere as little as possible withthose conditions; also, that the Bill shouldbe submitted confidentially to a number of leading employers, and, after their views hadbeen ascertained, a further Report should bemade to the Cabinet.The Cabinet encountered some difficultyin reconciling the provisions of the CoalminesAct, 1926, with the terms of the Washington hours convention. It was suggested that, following the example of some of the Continental Powers, itmight be possible to find general words whichwould enable the Washington Hours convention to be accepted without infringing the terms ofthe Coalmines Act.The Cabinet agreed (a) That the Minister of Labour should consult the Law Officers of theGrown as to the draft of a Clausefor incorporation in the Bill,preferably drawn in general terms,the object of which should be,while conforming to the provisionsof the Washington Hours Convention,to comply with the terms of theCoalmines Act, 1926;(b) That, if the Law Officers were ableto approve or draft such a Clause,the proposals in the First InterimReport of the Committee on theWashington Hours Convention(Paper CP.-77 (27)) should be proceeded with:-5- (c) But that, if the Law officers were unable to advise that sucha Clause could be drawn, thequestion should be brought backto the Cabinet.
